subject: Sleep
title: Language Learning and Sleep
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Language Learning and Sleep.

hook.text: Students who slept after learning new foreign vocabulary recalled 20 percent more words than those who stayed awake.

buildup.text: New words are stored initially in the hippocampus alongside their meaning and pronunciation.

discovery.text: During sleep, these word memories are integrated into the brain's existing language network in the cortex.

twist.text: Playing the foreign words quietly during deep sleep improved recall further, a technique called TMR.

climax.text: Targeted memory reactivation works because the sleeping brain can process external cues without waking.

punchline.text: Sleep is your brain's language lab at night.

quiz.question: What is targeted memory reactivation during sleep?
options: Playing loud alarms to wake up for study
Playing learning cues during deep sleep to boost memory
Studying a textbook under the pillow
